title: High-End Home Sales in England and Wales Slip in September
text:
High-end home sales in England and Wales fell sharply in September as wrangling over Brexit hit a new fever pitch, according to official data published on Monday.



Deals of at least £1 million (US$1.28 million) sold and recorded with the Land Registry last month totaled 545, a 27% decline from the total reported in August, official figures show.



More: Tech Wealth Gives Boost to Younger Buyers in Super-Prime London

Luxury deals in London fell proportionally to the rest of the country, with 304 sales of £1 million or more recorded in September versus a little more than 400 in August.



As usual, the most expensive deal across England and Wales last month was a home in prime central London for £17 million. The top deal was a recently renovated Edwardian six-bedroom house at the end of a terrace block in Chelsea. It boasts a master suite that spans the entire top floor and a modern open floor plan, according to a former listing for the rowhouse.



There were only two deals in England and Wales over £10 million last month, the second of which was a stately manor in Surrey with an indoor swimming pool that sold for £15.25 million. The newly constructed property, with six bedrooms, a steam room and home gym, hit the market several years ago asking £23 million, Mansion Global previously reported.



From Penta: Rare Whiskey Remains World’s Best-Performing Luxury Asset

There’s a lag time of several weeks to months between the final sale and when the deal is recorded with the Land Registry. It means the monthly data report provides a general picture of the movement of the market, rather than final figures.



Beyond the luxury market, home sales overall contracted in September. They totaled 25,140 last month, down 18% from August, the data show.
